definitions.level1_resuscitation: Conditions that are threats to life or limb (or imminent risk of detioration) requiring immediate aggresive interventions
definitions.level2_emergent: Conditions that are a potential threat to life, limb or function, requiring rapid intervention
definitions.level3_urgent: Conditions that could potentially progress to a serious problem requiring emergency intervention. May be associated with significant discomfort or affecting ability to work or activites of daily living
definitions.level4_less_urgent: Conditions that relate to patient age, distress, or potential for deterioration or complications, which would benefit from intervention or reassurance within 1-2 hours
definitions.level5_non_urgent: COnditions that may be acute but non-urgent, as well as chronic conditions which may be part of a chronic problem, with or without evidence of detioration. The investigation or interventions for some of these illnesses or injuries could be delayed or even referred to other areas of the hospital or health care system.

respiratory_distress.description: Fatigue from excessive work of breathing, cyanosis, single-word speech or unable to speak, upper airway obstruction, lethargic or confused, intubated or requiring assisted breathing
Increased work of breathing, speaking in phrases or clipped sentences, significant or worsening stridor, but airway protected
Dyspnea, tachypnea, shortness of breath on exertion, no obvious increased work of breathing, able to speak in sentences, stridor without any obvious airway obstruction

hemodynamic_stability.description: Severe end-organ hypoperfusion: weak or thready pulse, hypotension, significant tachycardia or bradycardia, decreased level of consciousness. Could also appear flushed, febrile, toxic, as in septic shock
Borderline perfusion; unexplained tachycardia, postural hypotension (by history), or suspected hypotension (lower than normal or expected blood pressure for a given patient)

hemodynamic_stability.circulatory_status: Vital signs at the upper and lower ends of normal
hemodynamic_stability.description: Relevant to the presenting complaint, especially if they differ from the patientâ€™s normal values

level_of_consciousness.description: Unable to protect airway, continuous seizure, or progressive deterioration in level of consciousness.
Loss of orientation to person, place, or time; new impairment of memory, new onset confusion, agitation.
Use other modifiers to define CTAS.

temperature.condition: Immunocompromised (Neutropenia, chemotherapy, or on immunosuppressive drugs including steroids)
Looks well (fever as only positive SIRS criterion)

mechanism_of_injury.type: High-risk MOI (Motor Vehicle Crash, pedestrian struck, fall >18ft, penetrating injury to high-risk anatomical regions)
Moderate-risk MOI (Head trauma from MVC, pedestrian struck, fall >3ft, blunt object assault)
Moderate-risk MOI (Head trauma from MVC, MCC,  fall >3ft or 5 stairs, axial load to the head)

blood_glucose.presenting_complaint: Altered level of consciousness, confusion, hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia
Altered level of consciousness, confusion, hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia
Altered level of consciousness, confusion, hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia
Altered level of consciousness, confusion, hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia

dehydration.symptoms: Marked volume loss with classic signs of dehydration and shock
Dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, decreased skin turgor, decreased urine output
Stable vital signs with increasing thirst, concentrated urine, history of fluid loss
No symptoms but ongoing fluid loss or difficulty tolerating oral fluids

2nd_order_modifiers.revised_modifier: other signification chest pain, ripping or tearing
